Light-weighting vehicles reduces fuel consumption, extends range, and results in reduced GHG emissions.  Advanced composite plastics can play a key role in that weight reduction strategy with a potential for saving an average 40% over metal parts in the body structure, closures (exterior body panels), and interior of a vehicle -- such parts make up almost half the mass of a vehicle.
The material strategy being employed relates to a class of plastics called thermoplastics which can be readily recycled mechanically i.e. by grinding and reprocessing/ remanufacturing. column11: The specific Pilot Application and funding will be directed to the development of capability to produce heat treatable AA7xxx series aluminum alloys (and others) for use in the automotive industry. A bench-scale simulator will be installed (to be obtained from the McGill Department of Mining and Materials) and upgraded to provide a simulated belt casting, with temperature monitoring of the melt, the belt substrate, and the strip. This monitoring of heat fluxes, in concert with control over speed of pour and belt speed, different belt topographies and materials, and other information, will enhance current understanding of the solidification parameters for the strip casting in general, and as specifically relevant to the challenges of casting AA7xxx series alloys. As a quick metallurgical note, AA7xxx series aluminum alloys have compositions (with primary alloying elements of Magnesium, Copper, and Zinc) that offer higher strength, useful in automotive alloys, especially in potential impact components, where energy absorption and dissipation are required.

The two types of electron microscopes have different approaches - SEM uses reflected or knocked-off electrons, while TEM uses transmitted electrons. There were project delays as PDFS (Lantern Machinery Analytics) was unable to image samples with SEM, and the TEM operator was busy. 

Different imaging techniques were tried (laser diffraction, optical microscopy, UV microscopy, X-ray). UV Imaging provided good results to 400nm and there were challenges related to bleaching and clumping. The applicants didn't have access to cost-effective X-ray equipment, and the data acquisition times made it impossible to image meaningful volumes. 

In SEM, it was extremely difficult to distinguish individual particles due to clumping. In TEM, nice round particles were not visible. Zentek provided the samples and PDF did the digital image analysis using contractor support and some machine learning work was completed. Partners are still to decide on the return on investment to pursue this project further.

PDFS' Canadian operations bought Machinery Analytics, and they benefitted from learning about UV image generation, understanding SEM limitations, and faster UV image processing. Zentek was able to get exposure to machine learning in an operating environment and if they pursue further development it can be used for new material production and instrumentation evaluation.
